OK I understand this =
is an intentional feature, and that it would be costly to change it. It's n=
ot a blocking problem for me either (I can give up using annotations in leg=
acy test classes, and migrate each class atomically).

Below are details of=
 why this is hampering me.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david=
@...> wrote:
> If your test class extends TestCase, then the 3.8 rules are =
applied
> exactly.  There are still lots of tools that depend fairly strong=
ly 
> on that guarantee.

OK, so this is intentional. And I understand your=
 point that specifying the execution rules while mixing both 3.8 and 4.x ru=
les may be non-trivial.

> 1) In your current case, it would require very l=
ittle effort to
> annotate the remaining desired methods with @Test.

I don=
't understand: the problem is merely that the @Test annotation is not taken=
 into account as soon as the test class extends TestCase.
Maybe what you me=
an is, it would would require very little effort to
not extend TestCase? ye=
s of course, but this is a contrived SSSCE just to demonstrate the issue.

=
> Is there a real situation in which
> it is a significant amount of effort=
 to update a class all at once?

Again, I don't understand. What I have is =
a real situation where it is a significant amount of effort to remove TestC=
ase from the test hierarchy:

I just happened to stumble on a fairly big he=
ap of tests which are organized in a class hierarchy (OrderDaoTestCase DaoT=
estCase extends BaseTestCase extends TestCase). jUnit4 annotations are disr=
egarded in OrderDaoTestCase, as it indirectly extends TestCase.

If I want =
to benefit from jUnit4 annotations in OrderDaoTestCase, I can either:
- bre=
ak this hierarchy before extending BaseTestCase: this would be heavy work (=
lots of utilities in BaseTestcase, could have been written as static utilit=
ies or helper classes, but the legacy situation is that most of these usefu=
l utilities are based on instance methods or protected fields).
- simply ma=
king BaseTestCase not extend TestCase: that would break those test subclass=
es that do rely on being indirect TestCase subclasses (ex: non-static asser=
t methods).

> 2) Where did you look in the documentation?  Where would be =
a natural place to see this behavior described?

OK this is a trick questio=
n because I mentioned "the documentation" :o)
Your question made me search =
for the docs I had read, and I realized that most of them are not from the =
jUnit team (or on the jUnit website).
As far as the standard doc is concern=
ed, well, this issue is probably too far-fetched to deserve an entry in the=
 short cookbook (which no more describes 3.8-style anyway).
I expected I wo=
uld find it in the FAQ (must not be as frequent as I thought).

This is pro=
bably merely a subject for a tutorial on migrating from 3.8, which may seem=
 obsolete as of today, but I'm sure there still exists lots of 3.8 test cod=
e in the field.
